sp.p: A scrivener's shop hangs to sergeants maze, like a burr to a freeze coat.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: You must take a note of a bond.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay a pint of courtesy pulls on a pot of wine, in this tavern we'll dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Now if our wits be not in the wane, our knavery shall be at the full, they will ride them worse than Dromio rid his horse, for if the wine master their wits, you shall see them bleed their follies.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Every fox to his hole, the hounds are, at hand.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The sergeant's maze lies at pawn for the reckoning, and he under the board to cast it up.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The scrivener cannot keep his pen out of the pot, every goblet is an inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: The hackneyman he whisks with his wand, as if the tavern were his stable, and all the servants his horses, lost there up bay Richard, and white loaves are horsebread in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: It is well I have my acquittance, and he such a bond as shall do him no more good than the bond of a faggot, our knaveries are now come to the push, and we must cunningly dispatch all, we two will go see how we may appease our masters, you two how you may conceal the late marriage, if all fall out amiss, the worst is beating, if to the best, the worst is liberty.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then let's about it speedily, for so many irons in the together require a diligent plumber.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p:
My heart throbs, my ears tingle, my mind misgives me, since I hear such muttering of marriages in Rochester, my conscience which these eighteen years hath been frozen with congealed guiltiness, begins now to thaw in open grief, but I will not accuse myself till I see more danger, the good old woman mother Bombie shall try her cunning
upon me, and if I perceive my case is desperate by her then will I rather prevent, although with shame, then report too late, and be inexcusable. God speed good mother.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Welcome sister.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I am troubled in the night with dreams, and in the day with fears, mine estate bare, which I cannot well bear, but my practises devilish, which I cannot recall, if therefore in these same years there be any deep skill, tell what my fortune shall be, and what my fault is.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: In studying to be overnatural thou art like to be unnatural, and all about a natural: thou shalt be eased of a charge if thou thy conscience discharge, and this I commit to thy charge.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Thou hast touched me to the quick mother, I understand thy meaning, and thou well knowest my practice, I will follow thy counsel. But what will be the end?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Thou shalt know before this day end, farewell.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Now I perceive I must either bewray a mischief, or suffer a continual inconvenience, I must haste homewards, and resolve to make all whole, better a little shame than an infinite grief, the strangeness will abate the fault, and the bewraying wipe it clean away.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p:
Come fellows, 'tis almost day, let us have a fit
of mirth at Sperantus' door, and give a song to the bride.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: I believe they are asleep, it were pity to awake them.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: 'Twere a shame they should sleep the first night.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: But who can tell at which house they lie, at Prisius it may be, we'll try both.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Come let's draw like men.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Now, tune, tune I say, that boy I think will never profit in his faculty, he loses his rosin, that his fiddle goes cush, cush, like as one should go wetshod, and his mouth so dry, that he hath not spittle for his pin as I have.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: Marry sir you see I go wetshod and dry mouthed, for yet could I never get new shoes or good drink, rather than I'll lead this life, I throw my fiddle into the leads for a hobbler.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Boy, no more words, there's a time for all things though I say it that should not, I have been a minstrel these thirty years, and tickled more strings than thou hast hairs, but yet was never so misused.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Let us not brabble but play, tomorrow is a new day.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I am sorry I speak in your cast, what shall we sing?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: The love knot, for that's best for a bridal. Sing. God morrow fair bride, and send you joy of your bridal.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p:
What a mischief make the twanglers here? we have no trenchers to scrape, it makes my teeth on edge to hear such grating. Get you packing, or I'll make you wear double stocks, and yet you shall be never the
warmer.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: We come for good will, to bid the bride and bride groom, God give them joy.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Hers no wedding.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Yes your son and Prisius' daughter were married, though you seem strange, yet they repent it not I am sure.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: My son villain, I had rather he were fairly hanged.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: So he is sir, you have your wish.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Here fiddlers take this and not a word, here is no wedding, it was at Memphio's house, yet gramercy, your music though it missed the house hit the mind, we were a preparing our wedding gear.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir, I think it was Memphio's son that was married.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: O ho the case is altered, go thither then and be haltered for me.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: What's the alms?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: An angel.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I'll warrant there's some work towards, ten shillings is money in master mayor's purse.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Let us to Memphio's and share equally, when we have done all thou shalt have new shoes.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I such as they cry at the sizes, a mark in issues, and mark in issues, and yet I never saw so much leather as would piece ones shoes.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: No more, there's the money.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: A good handsel, and I think the maidenhead of your liberality.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Come here's the house, what shall we sing?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p:
You know Memphio is very rich and wise, and
therefore let us strike the gentle stroke, and sing a catch.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: The bride this night can catch no cold,
No cold, the bridegroom's young, not old,
Like ivy he her fast does hold,

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Then let them alone, they know what they do.
At laugh and lie down, if they play,
What ass against the sport can bray?
Such tick-tack has held many a day,

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Then let them alone, they know what they do,

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: God morrow mistress bride and send you a huddle.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What crowding knaves have we there, case up your fiddles, or the constable shall cage you up. What bride talk you of?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Here's a wedding in Rochester, and 'twas told me first that Sperantus' son had married Prisius' daughter, we were there, and they sent us to your worship, saying your son was matched with Stellio's daughter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Hath Sperantus that churl nothing to do but mock his neighbours, I'll be even with him, and get you gone, or I swear by the rood's body I'll lay you by the heels.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Sing a catch, here's a fair catch in deed, sing till we catch cold on our feet, and be called knave till our ears glow on our heads, your worship is wise sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Dromio shake off a whole kennel of officers, to punish these jarring rogues, I'll teach them to stretch their dried sheep's guts at my door, and to mock one that stands to be mayor.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I had thought they had been sticking of pigs, I heard such a squeaking, I go sir.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Let us be packing.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Where is my scabbard, every one sheath his science.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: A bots on the shoemaker that made this boot for my fiddle, 'tis too straight.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: No more words, 'twill be thought they were the four waites, and let them wring, as or the wags that set us on work, we'll talk with them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: They be gone sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: If they had stayed, the stocks should have stayed them. But sirrah, what shall we now do?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: As I advised you make a match, for better one house be cumbered with two fools than two.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: 'Tis true, for it being bruited that each of us have a fool, who will tender marriage to any of them that is wise, besides fools are fortunate, fools are fair, fools are honest.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ay sir, and more than that, fools are not wise: a wise man is melancholy for moonshine in the water, careful building castles in the air, and commonly hath a fool to his heir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: But what sayest thou to thy dames chasing?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nothing but all her dishes are chasing dishes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I would her tongue were in thy belly.

sp.speaker: Dro,
sp.p: I had as lief have a raw neat's tongue in my stomach.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marry if the clapper hang within an inch of my heart, that makes mine ears burn a quarter of a mile off. Do you not think it would beat my heart black and blue?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Well patience is a virtue, but pinching is worse than any vice, I will break this matter to Stellio, and if he be willing, this day shall be their wedding.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then this day shall be my liberty.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I if Stellio's daughter had been wise, and by my means cozened of a fool.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then sir I'll revolt, and dash out the brains of your devises.

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: Rather thou shalt be free.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Boy, this smoke is a token of some fire, I like not the luck of it. Wherefore should these minstrels dream of a marriage?

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: Alas sir they rustle into every place, give credit to no such words.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I will to Prisius, I cannot be quiet, and in good time I meet him, God morrow neighbour.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I cast the morrow in thy fate, and bid good night to all neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This is your old trick, to pick ones purse and then to pick quarrels, I tell thee, I had rather thou shouldst rob my chest than embezzle my son.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Thy son, my daughter is seduced, for I hear say she is married, and our boys can tell. How sayest thou, tell the truth or I'll grind thee to powder in my mill, be they married?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: True it is they were both in a church.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: That no fault, the place is holy.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And there was with them a priest.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why what place fitter for a priest than a church?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And they took one another by the hand.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Trush, that's but common courtesy.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And the priest spoke many kind words.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: That showed he was no dumb minister. But what said they, didst thou hear any words between them?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Faith there was a bargain during life, and the clock cried, God give them joy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Villain they be married.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nay I think not so.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Yes, yes, God give you joy is a binder, I'll quickly be resolved, Candius come forth.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I'll be put out of doubt. Livia come forth.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: The mitcher hangs down his head.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The baggage begins to blush.

sp.speaker: Half:
sp.p: Now begins the game.

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: I believe it will be no game for us.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: Are you married young master?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: I cannot deny it, it was done so lately.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: But thou shalt repent, it was done so soon.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Then 'tis bootless to ask you Livia.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: Ay, and needless to be angry.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.p: It shall pass anger, thou shalt find it rage.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: You gave your consent.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.p: Impudent giglot, was it not enough to abuse me but also to belie me?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: You sir agreed to this match.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: Thou brazen face boy, thinkest thou by learning to persuade me to that which thou speakest. Where did I consent, when, what witness?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: In this place yesterday before Dromio and Risio.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I remember we heard a contract between Memphio's son and Stellio's daughter, and that our good wills being asked which needed not, we gave them, which booted not.

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: 'Twas but the apparel of Accius and Silena, we were the persons.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.p: O villainy not to be born, wast thou privy to this practice?

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: In a manner.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I'll pay thee after a manner.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: And you oatmeal groat, you were acquainted with this plot.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Accessary as it were.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: Thou shalt be punished as principal: here comes Memphio and Stellio, they belike were privy, and all their heads were laid together to grieve our hearts.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Stellio, the assurance may be made tomorrow, and our children assured today.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Let the conveyance run as we agreed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You convey cleanly in deed, if cozenage be clean dealing, for in the apparel of your children you have conveyed a match between ours, which grieves us not a little.

sp.speaker: Mem:
sp.p: Nay in the apparel of your children you have discovered the folly of ours, which shames us overmuch

sp.speaker: Stel:
sp.p: But 'tis no matter, though they be fools they are no beggars.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: And though ours be disobedient, they be no fools.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: So now they tune their pipes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You shall hear sweet music between a hoarse raven and a screech owl.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Neighbours, let us not vary, our boys have played their cheating parts, I suspected no less at the tavern, where four four knaves met together.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: If it were knavery for four to meet in a tavern, your wor. wot well there were other four.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This villain calls us knaves by craft.

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: Nay truly I dare swear he used no craft, but means plainly.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This is worse, come half. tell truth and scape the rod.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: As good confess here being trussed, as at home with my hose about my heels.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay I'll tell thee, for 'twill never become thee to utter it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Well out with it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Memphio had a fool to his son which Stellio knew not, Stellio a fool to his daughter unknown to Memphio; to cozen each other they dealt with their boys for a match; we met with Lincio and halfpenny, who told the love between their master's children, the youth deeply in love, the fathers unwitting to consent.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I'll take the tale by the end; then we four met, which argued we were no mountains, and in a tavern we met, which argued we were mortal, and every one in his wine told his day's work, which was a sign we forgotten not our business, and seeing all our masters troubled with devises, we determined a little to trouble the water before they drunk, so that in the attire of your children our master's wise children bewrayed their good natures, and in the garments of our master's children yours made a marriage; this all stood upon us poor children and your young children, to show that old folks may be overtaken by children.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Here's a children in deed, I'll never forget it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I will, Accius come forth.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I forgive all, Silena come forth.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Neighbour, these things cannot be recalled, therefore as good consent, seeing in all our purposes also we missed the mark, for they two will match their children.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well of that more anon, not so suddenly lest our ungracious youths think we dare do no other, but in truth their love's stirs up nature in me.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Accius thou must be married to Silena. How art thou minded?

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What for ever and man. Ay Accius, what else?

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I shall never be able to abide it, it will be so tedious.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Silena thou must be betrothed to Accius, and love him for thy husband.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I had as lief have one of clouts.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Why Silena?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why look how he looks.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: If you will not another will.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I thank you for mine old cap.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: And if you be so lusty lend me two shillings.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: We are happy, we missed the foolish match.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come you shall presently be contracted.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Contract their wits no more, they be shrunk close already.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Well father here's my hand, strike the bargain.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Must he lie with me?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: No Silena, lie by thee.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I shall give her the humble bees kiss.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: What dost thou think them rats, and fearest they shall be poisoned?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: You Vicinia, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Harken, about eighteen years ago I must thee a son Memphio, and thee a daughter Stellio.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p:
I had at that time two children of mine own, and being poor, thought it better to change them than kill them, I imagined if by device I could thrust my children into your houses, they should be well brought up in their youth, and wisely provided for in their age,
nature wrought with me, and when they were weaned I sent home mine in stead of yours, which hitherto you have kept tenderly as yours: growing in years I found the children I kept at home to love dear, at first like brother and sister, which I rejoiced at, but at length too forward in affection, which although inwardly I could not mislike, yet openly I seemed to disallow: they increased in their loving humours, I ceased not to chastise them for their loose demeanours, at last it came to my ears, that my son that was out with Memphio was a fool, that my daughter with Stellio was also unwise, and yet being brother and sister, there was a match in hammering betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What monstrous tale is this?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And I am sure incredible.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Let her end her discourse.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I'll never believe it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My very bowels earned within me, that I should be author of such vild incest, an hindrance to lawful love, I went to the good old woman mother Bombie to know the event of this practice, who told me this day I might prevent the danger, and upon submission escape the punishment, hither I am come to claim my children, though both fools, and to deliver yours both loving.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Is this possible, how shall we believe it?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I cannot sink into my head.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p:
This trial cannot fail, your son Memphio had a mole under his care, I framed one under my child's care by art, you shall see it taken away with the juice of mandrake, behold now for your sons, no herb can undo that nature hath done. Your daughter
Stellio hath on her wrist a mole, which I counterfeited on my daughter's arm, and that shall you see taken away as the other. Thus you see I do not dissemble, hoping you will pardon me, as I have pitied them.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: This is my son, oh fortunate Memphio!

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This is my daughter, more than thrice happy Stellio?

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: How happy is Maestius thou blessed Serena, that being neither children to poor parents, nor brother and sister by nature, may enjoy their love by consent of parents and nature.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Solt, I'll not swap my father for all this.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What do you think I'll be cozened of my father, methinks I should not, mother Bombie told me my father knew me not, my mother bore me not, falsely bred, truly begotten, a bot's on mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mother Bombie told us we should be found cozeners, and in the end be cozened by cozeners' welfare mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I heard mother Bomby say that thou shalt die a beggar, beware of mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why have you all bene with mother Bomby?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: All, and as far as I can see foretold all.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: In deed she is cunning and wise, never doing harm, but still practising good, seeing these things fall out thus, are you content Stellio the match go forward.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Ay, with double joy, having found for a fool a wise maid, and finding between them both exceeding love.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Then to end alliars, our children's matches shall stand with our good liking, Livia enjoy Candius.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Candius enjoy Livia.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p:
How shall we recompense fortune, that to our
loves hath added our parents good wills?

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: How shall we requite fortune, that to our loves hath added lawfulness, and to our poor estate competent living?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Vicinia thy fact is pardoned, though the law would see it punished, we be content to keep Silena in the house with the new married couple.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And I do maintain Accius in our house.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Come my children, though fortune hath not provided you lands, yet you see you are not destitute of friends, I shall be eased of a charge both in purse and conscience, in conscience, have revealed my lewd practice, in purse, having you kept of alms.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Come if you be my sister it's the better for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Come brother, methinks it's better than it was, I should have been but a bald bride, I'll eat as much pie as if I had been married.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Let's also forgive the knavery of our boys since all turns to our good haps.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Agreed, all are pleased now the boys are unpunished ▪

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Nay soft, take us with you, and seek redress for our wrongs, or we'll complain to the mayor.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p:
I arrested Memphio's boy for an horse after much mocking, at the request of his fellow wags, I was content to take a bond jointly of them all, they had me into a tavern, there they made me, the scrivener, and the sergeant drunk, pawned his maze for the wine, and sealed me an obligation nothing to the purpose,
I pray you read it.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: What wags be these? Why by this bond you can demand nothing, and things done in drink, may be repented in soberness, but not remedied.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Sir, I have his acquittance, let him sue his bond.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I'll cry quittance with thee.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: And I, or it shall cost me the laying on freely of my maze.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: And I'll give thee such a dash with a pen as shall cost thee many a pound, wish such a noverimt as cheap side can show none such.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Do your worst, our knaveries will revenge it upon your children's children.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Thou boy, we will pay the hire of the horse, be not angry, the boys have been in a merry cozening vain, for they have served their masters of the same sort, but all must be forgotten, now all are content but the poor fiddlers, they shall be sent for to the marriage and have double fees.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You need no more send for a fiddler to a feast, than a beggar to a fair.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This day we will feast at my house.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Tomorrow at mine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The next day at mine.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Then at mine the last day, and even so spend this week in good cheer.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then we were best be going whilst every one is pleased, and yet these couples are not fully pleased, till the priest have done his worst.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Come sergeant we'll toss it this week, and make thy maze arrest a boiled capon.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p:
No more words at the wedding, if the mayor should
know it, I were in danger of mine office.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then take heed how on such as we are, you show a cast of your office.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: If you mace us, we'll pepper you.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Come sister, the best is, we shall have good cheer these four days.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And be fools for ever.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: That's none of our upseckings.
